fields.description:
Bitbucket has the ability to add alerts in the header bar:

!Screenshot 2017-11-15 09.24.26.png|width=400!

However, this is not public API so is not available to plugin developers. It would be great if plugin developers could utilise this location to add their (actionable) alerts for their plugins.

For the purposes of this issue, providing plugins a way to show an alert for an actionable item (e.g. a misconfiguration or authentication issue) would give plugin authors the means to do so without needing to build their own solution. 
h4. What is an alert?

Alerts (as they are currently used by Bitbucket Server) are actionable items for a user and/or admin; i.e. the user can do something to make the alert go away by resolving the issue it is telling them about, e.g. setting their timezone, or configuring the instance's base URL.
h4. What an alert isn't:

Alerts are not notifications of events/activity that might be interesting to the user, for instance a notification about pull request activity or changes to a repository. These kinds of passive snippets of information are (usually) non-actionable items and are (usually) customised for a user based on their activity.
fields.summary: Make Alert JavaScript API public

fields.description:
When attempting to view the diff of a file that contains only whitespace changes with "Ignore whitespace" turned on the diff fails to load and the spinner remains. The following JavaScript error will appear on the console:

{{Uncaught TypeError: Cannot read property 'hunks' of undefined}}

h2. Workaround

* Go to the diff for an unaffected file
* Turn off "Ignore whitespace" in the menu at the top of the diff
fields.summary: Loading unified diff of file with whitespace only changes and ignore whitespace fails

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
Webhooks do not allow Basic Authentication to be transmitted.  There are CI processes that are not compatible with standard 3rd-party add-on calls.

h3. Suggested Solution
Allow for Basic Authentication.

h3. Why this is important.
From the initial use-case:
{quote}Customer's pipelines do not use the software configuration management (SCM);
pooling the repositories is done externally via shell scripts, i.e. git clone commands.
In this context, the use of Atlassian plugin Webhook to Jenkins for Bitbucket will not be beneficial,
because it expects SCM checkout + property statement be configured in a pipeline job.{quote}
 
h3. Workaround 
{quote}* [I]nclude a SCM in a pipeline job
* Create an addition ( proprietary ) layer that permits to parse BitBucket webhooks and to trigger the corresponding CI pipeline jobs (may be achieved with curl command and groovy script).{quote}
fields.summary: As an Admin I would like the native Webhooks feature to allow Basic Authentication

fields.description:
h3. Summary
"feature" prefix is not added to the branch name automatically when bugfix branch model is disabled in repository settings in Bitbutcket server.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
Jira integrated with Bitbucket server.
# Go Repository settings in Bitbucket Server 
# Select Branching model
# Check "Use custom settings" in Project settings inheritance
# Remove the check in Bugfix in Branch prefixes.
# Press Save
# Go Jira
# Open an issue
# Click "Create branch" in Development
# Feature is selected in Branch type. but "feature" prefix is not added to the branch name.

h3. Expected Results
Expected branch name: 
 feature/AAAA-1111-xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx

h3. Actual Results
Actual branch name: 
 AAAA-1111-xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx
 !Create_branch_-_Bitbucket.jpg|thumbnail! 

h3.Workaround
Re-select "Feature" Branch type in Branch type dropdown list.
fields.summary: "feature" prefix is not added to the branch name automatically when bugfix branch model is disabled in repository settings in Bitbutcket server

fields.description:
In Bitbucket Server 4.x and earlier, when commits are streamed for indexing, the indexer relied on an implicit behavior in the Git SCM that automatically set {{\-\-ignore-missing}} while building the {{git rev-list}} command. If multiple commits were provided to include, or if _any_ commits were provided to exclude, {{\-\-ignore-missing}} would be set.

That behavior was deprecated in Bitbucket Server 4.6, which allowed specifying whether to ignore missing commits explicitly, and it was fully removed in 5.0. However, the indexing code was not updated at that time to explicitly enable ignoring missing commits. As a result, where indexing in 4.x and earlier ignored missing commits and continued indexing, 5.0 and newer now fail with an error similar to this:

{noformat}

com.atlassian.bitbucket.commit.NoSuchCommitException: Commit '0498b0ed416966766c2141c5666c83c0f6bd327c' does not exist in repository 'repo'.
 at com.atlassian.bitbucket.scm.git.command.GitCommandExitHandler.newNoSuchCommitException(GitCommandExitHandler.java:167)
 at com.atlassian.bitbucket.scm.git.command.GitCommandExitHandler.evaluateStdErr(GitCommandExitHandler.java:70)
 at com.atlassian.bitbucket.scm.git.command.GitCommandExitHandler.onError(GitCommandExitHandler.java:197)

 at com.atlassian.bitbucket.scm.DefaultCommandExitHandler.onExit(DefaultCommandExitHandler.java:31)
 at com.atlassian.bitbucket.scm.BaseCommand.callExitHandler(BaseCommand.java:146)

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

REST API endpoint for the default branch returns a 404 for empty repositories when just created by Bitbucket:
{noformat}
projects/pkey/repos/rslug/branches/default
{noformat}
h3. Suggested Solution

When using the REST point:
 * for empty repos: return the equivalent of the "Not defined" value shown in the webpage (see attached screenshot).
 * for the repos with an invalid default, 404 is legitimate (current behavior)

h3. Workaround

Use a try/catch block and post-process the list of 404 repos with /branches to separate the really empty from the misconfigured.
fields.summary: Default branch REST API 404

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

REST API endpoint for repository browsing returns a 404 for valid repositories that are empty.

{noformat}
 projects/pkey/repos/rslug/browse
{noformat}


h3. Suggested Solution

When using the browse REST point:
For empty repos: return a valid request with with no content or a useful message.

h3. Workaround

Use a try/catch block and post-process the list of 404 repos to know which ones are really empty.
fields.summary: Repository Browse REST API 404

fields.description:
Right now it's possible to mark whole pull request as "needs work", but it's not very practical. 

Often a lot of time passes between review and the fix and reviewers just forget which issues should be solved before the pull request can be considered approved. Reviewers need a way to see all issues they are considering as blocking.

Reviewer can use tasks to mark blocking issues, but authors can mark the tasks as done themselves. We need something like tasks, but the tasks that only reviewer can mark as "done".

My suggestion is to add a checkbox to a comment box with a label "needs to be resolved". Having comments like that should block merging until the reviewer marks the issue as resolved (resolution can be an actual fix, or just a talk that convinces reviewer that no fix needed). And reviewer should be able to see a list with all comments marked as this.

One of the options is to mark the whole pull request as "Needs work" when such comment exists, but please note that "Needs work" is while much better than "Reject", is still a slightly irritating name for a button, and when doing pull request it's very important to keep level of stress as low as possible.

Most often than not we don't really need to mark a PR as "Needs work", we just need an answer from the author. And, before that answer is received, we want to block the pull request from being merged. It's not like it "Needs work", it more like it "Needs resolution" or something. Right now reviewers tend to not use that button because of that. Please consider to rename it to something even less disturbing.
fields.summary: Mark comments as "needs to be resolved"

This occurs when multiple rescopes for a given pull request are processed in one go and the first rescope merges the pull request, and subsequent rescopes add new contributors.

The merge rescope updates the pull request in the DB. When subsequent rescopes produce new participants the pull request used to create them is out of sync with the Hibernate session

Expected behaviour:
 # Commit by user2 gets added
 # Pull request gets merged by user2
 # Commit by user 3 gets added to the branch, but the PR doesn't show any activity
 # user2 gets added as a participant but user3 does not

 # Pull request gets merged by user2
 # user2 and user3 both try to get added as contributors Hibernate throws an exception because we are trying to update an out of date object

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
Currently any user can create webhooks via their personal repositories and repository admins can create webhooks for the repositories they administer. This can lead to users creating unexpected webhooks.

h3. Suggested Solution
Provide a feature to allow customers to disable webhooks completely, either via the add-on or via a property.

h3. Workaround 
There is no workaround.

h3. Summary

Bitbucket cannot delete tag consisting of numeric digits.
h3. Environment
 * Bitbucket Server v5.0.x

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Create a tag named "100200300" (from browser or CUI)
 # Delete the tag
 ** !Screenshot_2017-11-08_09_54_54.png|thumbnail!
 # Reload the page
 # Confirm the tag remains

h3. Expected Results

User can delete numeric tags on web UI.
h3. Actual Results

The below error is thrown in the browser console from {{commit-tags.js}}:
{noformat}
Uncaught TypeError: x.split is not a function
{noformat}

* It's able to delete numeric tag which starts with "0"

fields.description:
h3. Summary

Creating a branch with branch prefix set and naming it out of a Jira issue key, makes Bitbucket parse the issue key with the branch prefix breaking the issue link to Jira.
 
h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Setup a branch prefix, such as {{FB_}} for the feature branch;
# Create a new branch in Bitbucket's UI and name if out of a Jira issue key;
# It will create a branch called {{FB_JIRA-123}} and also a broken issue link called {{FB_JIRA-123}} under the *Issues* column in branches

h3. Expected Results
Bitbucket should parse the Jira issue link properly from the branch name

h3. Actual Results
Bitbucket is appending the branch prefix to the issue link breaking the link to the Jira issue.
fields.summary: Branch prefix appended to the issue links while creating a branch

fields.description:
Hi,

I'm opening this issue in know that this is not the project dealing with the 'jgitflow-maven-plugin', still I feel the need to get some attraction by Atlassian for this issue and have not found a place where this kind of question would fit:

The 'jgitflow-maven-plugin' is hosted on Bitbucket by Atlassian [1}. Unfortunate it has not have any activity by an Atlassian employee since 2015. At that time some PRs have been merged, but a release has never been done with the last changes.

Checking for support questions regarding jgitflow on the Atlassian site [2], shows that even though new questions come in, none has been answered since 2014.

It seems Atlassian has lost interest on this tool/library - that's fair, no big deal. But the incoming PRs [3] also show that the community is still interested in it.

Therefore I ask you to forward this issue to anyone within Atlassian who might be interested to find a solution and help the community to move forward with 'jgitflow'. Please think about opening/transferring the repo to the community so someone else could do at least a release with the latest changes/fixes not released yet.

/Domi

...sorry for the misplacement! 

[1] [https://bitbucket.org/atlassian/jgit-flow]

[2] [https://community.atlassian.com/t5/forums/searchpage/tab/message?advanced=false&allow_punctuation=false&q=jgitflow]

[3] [https://bitbucket.org/atlassian/jgit-flow/pull-requests/] 

 

p.s. yes I can do a private release, that's what we did - but I know others have the same issue and help is not hard to provide.
fields.summary: some love for jgitflow-maven-plugin

In Bitbucket Server 5.5.0, user is unable to delete application link from the UI.

 * v5.5.0

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Create application link to another Atlassian application.

h3. Workaround

Users can execute a CURL REST call to remove the application link. This call is made when you normally delete an application link.
 # From the Application Links page, select the EDIT icon for the application link you want to delete
 # In the browser address bar, after the *{{/edit/}}*, copy the ID listed in the URL. Here is an example URL below:
{noformat}
http://localhost:7990/plugins/servlet/applinks/edit/20ab2cd0-37c8-3935-8b0f-35aedfc4a712
{noformat}

{noformat}
curl -X DELETE -u USERNAME:PASSWORD -H "Accept: application/json"  http://localhost:7990/rest/applinks/3.0/applinks/20ab2cd0-37c8-3935-8b0f-35aedfc4a712
{noformat}

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
Renaming a project/repository in Bitbucket Server creates an alias that permits the repository to be accessed using the old URL (this was implemented with [BSERV-3751 - Allow historical aliasing of projects and repositories|https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/BSERV-3751]).

This permits repositories to be still accessible by clients without updating the {{remote}} address and helps in case of existing automated procedures (i.e. CI integrations) to not be disrupted by a repository rename.

At the same time this generates issues when a new repository with the same name of one of the aliases gets created. 
The creation invalidates the previous alias and makes all the integrations now point to the new repository and has the potential to disrupt long or critical operations by only adding a repository with the "wrong" name.

h3. Suggested Solution
Possible Solutions:
* Let the project admin set an option for the default behavior (Historical Aliases On/Off)
* When renaming a repository let the user choose to add a historical alias or not
* Highlight repositories having one or more active alias and let the repository admin delete the alias
* When creating a repository warn the user if that name is going to overwrite an existing alias

h3. Why this is important
 
In environments where there is lot of automation in place and is not possible to keep track of the automations in place this could cause errors or delays in case long operations need to be performed. 

In such environment having an automated operation fail is usually preferable to having the same operation performed using the wrong data (the new repository).

h3. Workaround 
It is possible to check the existing aliases in place for Bitbucket by checking the content of tables:
* {{bb_repository_alias}}
* {{bb_project_alias}}
fields.summary: As an administrator I would like to view and edit repository project aliases active for my instance

fields.description:
{panel:title=Atlassian status as of March 2020|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#deebff|titleBGColor=#deebff|bgColor=#ffffff}
Hi everyone,

Thanks for your feedback and advocacy on this suggestion. In [Bitbucket Server and Data Center 7.0|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucketserver/bitbucket-server-7-0-release-notes-990546638.html] we have introduced a new webhook - 'Source branch updated'. This webhook will send the pull request context when source branch of a pull request is updated e.g. new commits pushed to the source branch. You can check the sample payload on this [page.|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucketserver/event-payload-938025882.html]

Try it out and let us know how it goes.

Thanks!
Imran Khan, Product Manager - Bitbucket Server

{panel}
*Original description*

Related to BSERV-10278, webhooks are looking great and we're excited to integrate pull request support.

There doesn't seem to be a pull request event for when the pull request is updated. For example, somebody changes the title. Bitbucket Cloud has this as a pull request updated event:

[https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucket/event-payloads-740262817.html#EventPayloads-Updated.2]

GitHub's is pull request edited:

[https://developer.github.com/v3/activity/events/types/#pullrequestevent]

There also doesn't seem to be an event for when the proposed head changes, like if somebody pushes extra commits onto the pull request branch. GitHub calls  a "synchronize" event, and includes the pull request details including the new head commit sha for merging, another subtype of their pull request event. I'm not sure if Bitbucket Cloud sends this event. However it's pretty critical for rebuilding pull requests if the proposed code changes.

Thanks!
fields.summary: Pull request updated and synchronized webhooks

fields.description:
It's awesome that Bitbucket Server now includes Webhooks out of the box.

Unfortunately they don't seem to include as much information as the older post service webhook plugin:

[https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucketserver/post-service-webhook-for-bitbucket-server-776640367.html]

We rely on the commit message, and the commit author name and email to trigger accurate builds on Buildkite, all of which were included in the old hook but are not included in the new hook. The Bitbucket Server actor is not always the same as the commit author.

Bitbucket Cloud includes this information in push events:

[https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucket/event-payloads-740262817.html#EventPayloads-Push]

As another example, GitHub includes the commit information in their push events:

[https://developer.github.com/v3/activity/events/types/#pushevent]

We'd love to see this information in the Bitbucket Server payload so we can achieve parity and switch to advising our customers to use webhooks.
fields.summary: More comprehensive push webhook

fields.description: We have a complex project with 15 or so repositories. Two products use different combinations of these repositories, and sub-modules are nested three deep in some places. But this file would then display on the above the repository list like README files do within individual repositories.

fields.description: This really starts out as a question to make sure I understand some things before I'd suggest anything.  First a little background. I discovered that using TeamCity for continuous integration, we can report the status of a build to Bitbucket Server. This status can then be used to prevent merging of a pull request unless there is a successful build. During this discovery and implementation, I found out that Bitbucket Server creates what seem to be hidden commits in the repository that keep the resulting merge of the pull request. This kind of makes sense since Bitbucket is able to tell me if there will be merge conflicts. Obviously, this happens because the merge has already been performed. I think these are in refs with the format 'refs/pull-requests/#/merge'.  I have also figured out how to build these "merge" commits in TeamCity. Doing this I know whether or not the merge will even build, not just merge. Both of which are very important. First I'd like to know if my understanding is correct. If I do understand things properly, then I'd like to suggest a feature that attaches the build status of the merged commit to the associated pull request. This would allow people to prevent a merge if the merge would not build.
fields.summary: Pull request merge build status

h3. Summary

h3. Environment
* Bitbucket 5.3.2 or 5.4.0 (other versions may be affected as well)

h3. Steps to Reproduce
1. On a repo, set up branch permissions to prevent all changes:

a) Select *Branch pattern*

b) Enter {{refs/heads/release/*}}

c) Select *Prevent all changes*

d) Click *Create*

2. Edit a file through the Bitbucket Server GUI and make changes to it

3.Click *Commit*

4. Select *Create a pull request for this change*

5. As the *Branch name* enter {{release/somechange}}

6. Click *Create pull request*

h3. Expected Results

A message is displayed informing the user that branch permissions prevent the creation of the branch

h3. Actual Results
The following message is displayed to the user:

*A branch with this name already exists. Try another.*

h3.Workaround
Remove branch permissions or tell users to create pull requests for other branches than the one with the restrictive permissions applied to it.
fields.summary: Misleading error message is displayed when creating pull request for a target branch that prevents all changes

fields.description:
I'd like to have the ability, either when creating a pull request or reviewing a pull request, to mark two files in a diff as "related" so that they can be viewed side-by-side.

The use cases are when a file has changed type but is still related to another in a way (e.g. when a Java class file is converted to Kotlin), and when a file has moved directory and changed enough for Git to believe the file was removed+added elsewhere.
fields.summary: Allow files in a pull request diff to be linked as "related files"

fields.description:
In addition to the excellent "Find text in diff and context lines" feature that already exists, please implement a new "Find file" feature.

This would be especially helpful for large pull requests (i.e., pull requests with many files); instead of having to scroll to try to find the file, a "Find file" feature would allow us to quickly find a particular file.

This could be implemented either as a text box or, even better, as a dropdown combobox that contains the names of all the files in the pull request (or current commit).  Ideally, we could type part or all of a file name in a text portion of a combo box or select from a pre-populated list of filenames.
fields.summary: "Find file" feature

fields.description:
I love the "Show diff of" dropdown combo box that that enables us to quickly go to a particular commit within the pull request.

I just discovered an annoying issue, though, with that dropdown combo box when there are 7 or more commits.

When first I drop-down the "Show diff of" dropdown combo box, I see the first option (viz., "All changes in this pull request") and the first 6 commits.  When I then click on a commit that is past/after the 6th commit (7th or higher), I see the changes in that commit; that's good.

What's not so good is that if I subsequently drop-down the "Show diff of" dropdown combo box, it displays the first option (viz., "All changes in this pull request") and the first 6 commits.  I then have to click and drag the scrollbar on the right down to see the commit I'm currently viewing (I then see that that commit is highlighted/highlit in the dropdown combo box).

What would be better (i.e., more developer-friendly) is that when we drop-down the "Show diff of" dropdown combox a subsequent time, that we would immediately see the commit (i.e., the commit currently being viewed would immediately be in the "view port" of the dropped-down dropdown combobox) - and, of course, still highlighted/highlit - without us first having to click and drag the scrollbar on the right to scroll down to it.
fields.summary: "Show diff of" dropdown combox issue when there are 7 or more commits

fields.description:
h3. Summary

In versions of git prior to git 2.9.4, it is possible that a diff will not be able to be created for a pull request in instance where line endings are being translated between CRLF/LF modes. 
h3. Expected Results

A diff is produced and a user may navigate a pull request
h3. Actual Results

No diff is produced, and the following error exists in the logs when attempting to view/create a pull request
{code:java}
CommandFailedException: '/usr/bin/git commit -m Automatic merge --' exited with code 128 saying: error: commit is not possible because you have unmerged files.
hint: Fix them up in the work tree, and then use 'git add/rm <file>'
hint: as appropriate to mark resolution and make a commit.
fatal: Exiting because of an unresolved conflict.{code}
h3. Fix

Unfortunately this cannot be fixed in Bitbucket server as it is an issue with git itself. If you run into this problem, you must upgrade your git version. 

The fix itself is mentioned in the 2.9.4 [release notes|https://github.com/git/git/blob/v2.9.4/Documentation/RelNotes/2.9.4.txt]. Check the [Supported platforms page|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BitbucketServer/Supported+platforms] to confirm what version of git you must upgrade to.
fields.summary: Prior to git 2.9.4, pull request diffs may fail to be created due to line ending issues

fields.description:
Related to this page: https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucketserver/running-bitbucket-server-as-a-windows-service-776640048.html

The {{service.bat}} script that installs the BBS services in Windows, has a check for whether it's running in 32-bit or 64-bit system:

{code}
rem Check the JRE's architecture to use the correct service wrapper
"%JRE_HOME%\bin\java" -Xmx50M -version 2>&1 | "%windir%\System32\find" "64-Bit" >nul:
if errorlevel 0 goto x64
SET EXE=bserv.exe
goto setInst

:x64
SET EXE=bserv64.exe
...
{code}

Running the script in a 32-bit Windows (with a 32-bit JRE installed and {{JRE_HOME}} set)  fails because it picks up the 64-bit version of executables.

*Works fine in 64-bit Windows, either because the check works, or because the script always picks up the 64-bit exec ({{bserv64.exe}}).*
fields.summary: service.bat in ZIP archive doesn't pick the right executable for 32-bit Windows

fields.description:
h3. Summary

A pull request with merge conflicts shows a warning about the conflict with the More information link, which does not work properly if one changes from the Overview tab to any other tab and get back to the Overview.

Tested in 4.13.1 and 5.4

h3. Environment
- Bitbucket Server 4.13.1
- Bitbucket Server 5.x (tested in 5.4)
- Firefox 56.0
- Chrome Version 61.0.3163.100 (Official Build) (64-bit)
- Safari Version 11.0 (13604.1.38.1.6)

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create a PR with a merge conflict
# Click on the {{More Information}} link - it shows the dialog with instructions on how to solve the conflict
# Close the {{More information}} dialog
# Click on the {{Diff}} tab
# Return to the {{Overview}} tab
# Try to click on the {{More information}} once again - the dialog won't show up anymore

h3. Expected Results
- The dialog should show up after changing tabs

h3. Actual Results
- The dialog doesn't show up after changing tabs.

h3. Workaround.
- Refresh the pull request page. This will make the dialog to show up after changing tabs.
fields.summary: More information dialog does not work after changing tabs in a PR with merge conflict

fields.description:
Hi,

Currently, anonymous users are not allowed to see pull requests when a repository is public. We would like to see this changed.

Sometimes, we want to point users without an actual account to a pull request. Although they could not maintain the state of the pull request or comment on those, they could at least see what we plan to do with a pull request. This would also be very convenient for demo purposes.

If this cannot be the default behaviour, we would very welcome a configurable option to enable access for anonymous users to pull requests.

Thanks,

Michael
fields.summary: Allow to see pull requests for anonymous users

fields.description:
h3. Summary
When a username starts with a number or a special character (e.g. {{_}}), the repository access is not recorded for his personal repositories.

This leads to various side effects:
- the "Recently viewed" drop down does not show the repository
-- !image-2017-10-16-17-23-22-058.png|width=200px! 
- when creating a branch, the source repository is not the current one
- the "Repositories" list on the Bitbucket Server dashboard does not show the repository

h3. Environment
* tested with a PostgreSQL database

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create a user with a number as the starting character (e.g. {{1charlie}})
# Create a personal repository and allow "Public access"
## Access the list of "Recently viewed" repository
## Create a new branch 

h3. Expected Results
+Access the list of "Recently viewed" repository+
The last opened repository is being displayed.

+Create a new branch+
The current repository is shown as source repository.

h3. Actual Results
+Access the list of "Recently viewed" repository+
The repository is never shown.

+Create a new branch+
The repository accessed before the current one is displayed as source branch.
 
h3. Notes
- This happens because the {{repository_access}} table is not updated with a valid value for the user and the database.
- Any user accessing Bitbucket Server is affected by this behaviour, not just the user with the username starting with a number.
- No errors or logs are shown in the logs.
- This only happens with personal repositories and it is not possible to create a project starting with a special character ({{_}}) or a number


h3.Workaround
Not available.
fields.summary: Repository_access table is not updated when usernames start with a number or a special character (e.g. _)

fields.description:
We have a workflow where any pull request from a feature branch to development branch (master) will have to be merged using "Squash" commit. We also have a separate production branch (release) from where our release builds are generated.

We have added a rule to not allow any modifications without a Pull Request on both master and release. When we have to make a new release, we would like to create a pull request from master to release branch. But if the merge strategy is "Squash", then those 2 branches would diverge.

So, we would like to make it a "Fast-forward only" merge if the source branch is master. Any merges from hotfix branches to release directly should still be "Squash" commits.

I know we can choose this option in each pull request individually, but it is error prone and would be more convenient to set it in the merge strategies setting to automatically choose the required type based on the source (and optionally target) branch.
fields.summary: Choosing merge strategy of a Pull Request based on the source branch

fields.description:
Working with a Git-Flow approach and well spaced out release cycles, pull requests for future releases often sit approved and not merged for significant periods, as release builds are scheduled for testing after all changes are merged, to ensure that all features and fixes for that release function together as expected. In the meantime the current release is actively worked on and tested as per the develop=>feature=>develop=>release branch flow, so the develop branch remains reserved for the current release.

Accordingly, it would be very useful if the pull requests page allowed users to filter Approved pull requests in and out of the list, as this would reduce list sizes, clarify items pending review, and allow easy oversight of already approved items by a team leader.
fields.summary: Filter Pull Requests by Approved status

fields.description:
h4. Symptoms

When loading an {{IndexedCommit}} from {{CommitIndex.getCommit(Sting commitId)}} and accessing {{repository.getProject().getName()}} on any of the repositories returned by {{IndexedCommit.getRepositories()}}, the following exception is thrown:

{noformat}
2017-10-11 00:00:01,925 ERROR [threadpool:thread-2]  c.a.s.i.c.DefaultTransferableStateManager Error while processing asynchronous task

fields.description:
Hi,

I was going to request a new feature but couldn't find that hyperlink because I was on the Diff tab.

I went back to the Overview tab and found the footer with the following information:
{noformat}
Git repository management for enterprise teams powered by Atlassian Bitbucket
Atlassian Bitbucket v5.3.1
Documentation
Contact Support
Request a feature
About
Contact Atlassian
Atlassian
{noformat}
I see that the Commits tab also has the same footer.

The Diff tab, however, does not.

It should very simple to add the footer to the Diff tab.  In fact, due to the fact that it appears on both the Overview and Commits tab, I'm concluding that someone explicitly excluded it from displaying on the Diff tab; it should be quite simple to remove the code that's excluding it from the Diff tab.

TIA,

Art Bergquist
fields.summary: Include footer on Diff tab

fields.description:
Bitbucket server. Pull-requests.

I am software architect who reviews the API specifications from different project teams.

We use swagger files as API specifications. Every change to API specification requires Pull-Request with approvals from:
1) software architect

2) at least one lead developer from server side team

3) at least one lead developer from client side team

I work with a couple of teams and projects simultaneously.

I see 20-40 different pull requests at same time in the list.

I need the instrument to track the status of my reviews with the following statuses of each pull-request:
1) I need to review this but not seen it
2) I reviewed and approved this, PR allowed to merge but not merged, maybe waiting approvals from other reviewers or software release.

3) I reviewed this and I have the open questions ( unresolved comments in PR)
4) I reviewed this, my questions resolved, PR has updated and I need to review it again.

Because one PR may have 3-10 reviewers, there is non-trivial task to sort PR's by the states mentioned before.
fields.summary: Pull-request review status tracking

fields.description:
*Problem*

App UX Designers predominately use Sketch as their tool of choice. The Sketch team has defined an open file format with APIs. When these files are stored in a GIT repo, there is no decent tool to show the difference between 2 versions. [This is an example|https://github.com/mathieudutour/git-sketch-plugin] but it is subpar. 

 

*Solution Suggestion*

Support a visual diff of Sketch files in stash highlighting what was removed and what was added just like in source code. 

 

*Conditions of Satisfaction*

Make designers and programmers happy to use one awesome tool.

Designers can submit pull requests that developers can comment on.
fields.summary: As a developer, I want to see a visual difference of design source files so that I know precisely what was changed

fields.description:
We want to use Bitbucket Mirroring a lot within the company and would like to request an addition to the LFS-workings.

Currently, LFS-files are cached on the mirror for about 4 hours. Given the fact mirroring helps with bandwidth and network latency, I would like the LFS-files be permanently mirrored on the Bitbucket Mirror and not in cached-format.

This will greatly improve the Bitbucket Mirroring functionality.
fields.summary: Store LFS permanently on Bitbucket Mirror

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
When JIRA is linked with Bitbucket Server, the user is able to create branches on Bitbucket from JIRA issues. 
On the branch creation screen, JIRA suggests a branch name which contains the issue key, which is necessary for the link to be established. If the user removes the issue key from the name, the branch won't be linked to the JIRA issue. This may lead to some confusion, as some users may expect the branch to be linked, as it was created from the JIRA issue.

h3. Suggested Solution
Since the link between the branch and a JIRA issue is based on the issue key in the branch name, and the branch name is editable, my suggestion includes:
* A warning to be shown on the branch creation popup when the user is creating a branch from a JIRA issue without including the issue key in the branch name. This warning could either show up as a red warning under the Branch Name field, updated in real time as the user removes the issue key from the branch name, or a message to be acknowledged when the user tries to create a branch without the issue key.
* If opting by a message to be acknowledged, I also suggest the possibility to disable this feature, as some users may find it annoying.
fields.summary: Display warning when creating a branch not including the issue key

fields.description: On the Overview page of a repo there's a box with the repo's URL. Previously, the URL in this box started with "git@", but recently it seems to have changed to "UserName@" ("GavinAndereggNATIONAL"@, in my case). For teams using SSH and ForwardAgent to control repos on machines shared between users, this can be a source of confusion for some when a repo is cloned. There's now a bit of internal learning required to know how to update the URL and potentially how to fix .git/config files – not the end of the world, but something that has surprised us a couple of time so far.
fields.summary: Repo URLs should start with git@ instead of UserName@ (or have an option to do so inside a team)

fields.description:
When doing code review of pull requests, reviewers are forced to constant e-mails with comments from other reviewers as well. The large volume of e-mails causes reviewers to be interrupted or simply ignore Bitbucket e-mail altogether. It doesn't help that the format for replies to a comment and entirely new comments are presented the almost identically. The original comment that was replied to is dark gray text on light gray background, so the conversation is hard to follow.

For Bitbucket to excel further into the enterprise space, we need better control over e-mails/notifications. Sane defaults are important too: When making a comment, I should not receive e-mail notifications for every other thing that happens to that pull request.
fields.summary: E-mail notifications only for replies to comments on PRs

fields.description:
After I edit a comment, the date says "44 mins ago (A moment ago)", missing the word "edited":

 !screenshot-1.png|thumbnail! 

Only after I reload the page it changes to "48 mins ago (*edited* 4 mins ago):

 !screenshot-2.png|thumbnail!
fields.summary: Comment's "Edited X ago" misses the "edited" word after comment is edited

fields.description:
Ability to send triggers from build status is handy, but often developers want only to know if build failed. Currently, this is not possible.

Add option to select Build status failed only.

!image-2017-10-10-09-08-45-391.png!
fields.summary: Allow to trigger webhook notification *only* from build failure

fields.description:
When a fork's branch diverges from the upstream branch, ref sync displays a "Synchronize" button on the branch. When "Merge" is selected, the UI only waits one minute for the merge to complete, but the server (by default) will allow 5 minutes for merges to complete. This means the UI may display a "Server unreachable" popup _even though the merge eventually succeeds_.

Similar to BSERV-7360, which updated the UI to wait the configured server-side merge duration for pull requests, ref sync merges should also wait the configured duration.
fields.summary: The UI only waits 1 minute for ref sync merges

fields.description:
In Bitbucket Server 4.3, BSERV-7360 was fixed and the UI was updated to wait the configured server-side merge timeout when merging a pull request _and when checking if it could be merged_. It appears the "canMerge" portion of that fix was almost immediately regressed, in 4.4.0. As a result, while the UI will still wait the configured merge timeout when _merging_ a pull request, _viewing_ a pull request can still show a "Server unreachable" popup while checking mergeability.

Because the mergeability check result is cached, so long as the pull request doesn't change, refreshing the screen after a timeout will (generally) show the correct mergeability state very quickly, since it doesn't need to perform a new merge.
fields.summary: Pull request "canMerge" checks only wait 1 minute before timing out

fields.description:
h3. Summary
* Merge commits, whose commit messages contain Jira issue keys, stopped displaying Jira issue keys in the *Issues* column.

h3. Environment
* Bitbucket Server 5.4.0 integrated with Jira 7.3.1, using standard OAuth for authentication and having the consumer tokens created as usual.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Perform a merge commit
# Go to the *Commits* page
# See that no Jira issue key is presented next to the merge commit
# See that no merge commit is shown in the Development panel of the Jira ticket.

h3. Expected Results
* The Jira issue key shows up with a link to the actual issue in Jira side.
* The Development Panel in the Jira issue shows the merge commit.

h3. Actual Results
* No Jira issue keys are presented next to the merge commit, as can be seen in the image attached.
* The merge commit is also not visible from JIRA, as can be seen in the image attached.
* No errors are written in the logs.

h3. Notes
* This is working as expected in previous versions such as 5.1, 5.2 and 5.3, as can be seen in the images attached.

h3.Workaround
* There is currently no workaround.
fields.summary: Merge commits are not linked to JIRA issues

fields.description:
This one is directly related to -----BSERV-3751- and also to https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/BSERV-10293

Previously the feature "Allow historical aliasing of projects and repositories" has been integrated, which from my perspective is breaking Bitbucket for previous users that rely on the fact that the old URL are not valid anymore, which was and is the expected behaviour. This change changes this default behaviour and in our case causing troubles. From my point of view this has to be configurable either globally or on renaming a repository by providing a checkbox "Alias to old repo?". In both cases the default doesn't matter as long it is a choice, but I'd vote to default to the old behaviour.
fields.summary: Allow to omit redirection feature when renaming a repostiory

fields.description: We'd like to have a dashboard to view all commits for all repositories (like [https://blog.bitbucket.org/2013/03/04/the-new-bitbucket-dashboard-all-your-code-activity-all-in-one-...|https://blog.bitbucket.org/2013/03/04/the-new-bitbucket-dashboard-all-your-code-activity-all-in-one-place/]).
fields.summary: Include commits on dashboard

fields.description: Be able to use file:// prefix in order to import repositories from the file system when using the Bitbucket Import Repository UI.
fields.summary: Allow importing from file system using UI.

fields.description:
{panel:title=Atlassian status as of March 2020|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#deebff|titleBGColor=#deebff|bgColor=#ffffff}
Hi all,

Good news! In Bitbucket Server 7.0 we added Advanced Auditing which helps admins and security teams to have a global view on auditing events.

You can find more information in the Bitbucket Server 7.0 [release notes|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucketserver/bitbucket-server-7-0-release-notes-990546638.html] and Advanced Auditing [documentation|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucketserver/audit-logging-in-bitbucket-server-776640417.html].

Please, don't hesitate to leave feedback on the feature in the comments. This will help us to priorities further development.

Anton Genkin
 Product Manager Bitbucket Server
{panel}
 

Currently, only Repository-level audit log has a UI option, and some audit logs are not included in the UI. This makes finding certain audit events hard for admins. Examples:
 * Tracking global changes (such as permission grants)
 * Tracking pull and or push events

h3. Suggested Solution

Add a Global Audit Log UI in the Administration section of Bitbucket Server. Add the ability to select audit events to include in the UI per repository.
h4. Note

(i) The Audit Logs in the UI will only contain the last 500 actions.
h3. Why is this important?

This would allow admin users to have more visibility into global and repository changes being made. Especially in the case of companies with siloed teams, where Bitbucket Server admins do not have access to the filesystem.
h3. Workaround

The audit log files in {{<bitbucket-home>/log/audit}} can be searched to find the entries.
fields.summary: Extend Audit logging UI

h3. Problem Definition

Opening the support tools page starts log analysis by default. If the log file size is huge it may take time to complete and need to cancel.

h3. Suggested Solution

No workaround
fields.summary: Disable default log analysis which gets started when navigate to Support Tools page

fields.description:
When running {{git}} processes, Bitbucket Server typically relies on a {{Repository}} being passed, or an explicit working directory being set. If neither happens, the system defaults the working directory to {{$BITBUCKET_HOME/tmp}}.

{{git}} has a built-in behavior that, when the directory where it's run isn't a bare repository and doesn't contain a {{.git}} directory, it walks "up" parent directories searching for one.

When these two behaviors intersect, it can produce unexpected behavior. This is particularly noticeable (or perhaps _unnoticeable_) when running Bitbucket Server via AMPS as part of developing a plugin. In that case, {{$BITBUCKET_HOME}} tends to be in {{target/bitbucket/home}} within the Maven project, _which is in a Git repository_. As a result, when {{git}} processes don't have a working directory and are run in {{$BITBUCKET_HOME/tmp}}, the default behavior of walking "up" the parents finds the _plugin's_ {{.git}} directory and considers it the repository root. This can defeat some integration tests, and result in different behavior under test than when, say, Bitbucket Server is explicitly installed on a real server (where it generally is not inside a Git repository).
fields.summary: Git processes without working directories can exhibit unexpected behaviors

fields.description: When calling any of the Git SCM's {{CommandFactory}} types, the method parameters are marked as {{@Nonnull}}, but the implementations don't always enforce it. In certain cases, that actually allows starting invalid {{git}} processes which can fail in unexpected ways.
fields.summary: Git command factories do not null-check their parameters

I often put screenshots into Bitbucket PRs to show the result of a PR or highlight a bug in the code and it is cumbersome to have to save the screenshot locally and upload.

Reference:

https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFCLOUD-23235

fields.description:
The following PR merge condition is *too confusing*, and should be reworded for clarity:
{quote}*Requires a minimum of *X* successful builds*
 If there are more than the specified number of builds, all of them will have to be successful in order to merge the pull request
{quote}
In my best understanding, what this setting means actually: *require at least X builds, and all builds must be successful* ([source|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucketserver044/using-bitbucket-server/using-pull-requests-in-bitbucket-server/checks-for-merging-pull-requests]).

From the linked source, I can already conclude:
 * For each PR, the number of builds is counted only for the last commit in the PR, so *if you update the PR* (e.g. even with a zero-commit rebase), then *the count will reset*.
 * The setting above 1 is rather meaningful for the case when *you have multiple builds* set up in your CI tool for the same project, then *one PR commit triggers multiple builds*, and all those must pass.

By the way, I also know that *if the build fails due to a problem with the CI tool* (unrelated to the commit), then *the build can be restarted*, *and the status of that build will be updated*, instead of incrementing the counter ([source|https://community.atlassian.com/t5/Bitbucket-questions/Why-does-a-minimum-number-of-builds-mean-that-all-builds-must-be/qaq-p/208371]).

 

But, I had to derive all these information from somewhere in order to understand how this condition works. While the official documentation was quite helpful already, I still think that the name of the condition should not be so misleading (I don't think it's grammatically correctly expressed), and *the short help text should indicate somehow that the builds are counted for the last commit* (without sacrificing its intended length of course). Because, it's great that we got an official documentation, but the *best is when normally I can use an application without having to read external docs about it,* and the documentation would be there to help me when I have an unusual problem. So yes, I also imply that the short help text should be updated too.
fields.summary: Reword "Requires a minimum of X successful builds"

fields.description: Add a "star" button on a repository navigation on the left side
fields.summary: Make "Add to Favorites" easier

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

Logging into Bitbucket and opening a random project, then opening the list of branches.

If the integration between Jira and Bitbucket is implemented some branches have a link to a specific Jira issue they're related to.

When clicking on one of the links, Bitbucket opens a "div" where content from Jira is rendered.

This inline div isn't visible for Braille devices, so users in need to use such devices are only able to notice there's something, though they're unable to get the content.

The HTML code reported starts with:
{code:xml}
<div id="branch-jira-issues-dialog" class="aui-popup aui-dialog jira-issues-dialog" style="...
{code}
h3. Suggested Solution

Make the inline div accessible for Braille devices.
h3. Why this is important

To extend Bitbucket accessibility for visually impaired users to Application Links functionalities.
fields.summary: Make Jira issue field accessible for visually impaired users

fields.description:
Hi Support,

Currently there is no way to get list of all active pull request of particular Bitbucket Project. Currently I have 9-10 repository in a Project and I have to navigate to each repository to check active pull requests.

Please have functionality to get list of all active pull request of projects so that we don't have to navigate to each repos.

Reference Question : https://community.atlassian.com/t5/Git-questions/How-to-get-list-of-active-Pull-Requests-for-particular-Bitbucket/qaq-p/645880#U649915

Thanks,
Hardik
fields.summary: Ability to get list of active Pull Requests for particular Bitbucket Project / complete projects

fields.description:
When you add a comment to a file and author commits a new version of the file you no longer see that comment there. It's visible only in Overview tab. It's then quite difficult to keep track if changes requested by the comment have been done in the file if you have to switch between tabs to see the comment or the diff.

Comments to given file should be available in the file diff through the whole PR lifetime.
fields.summary: Keep comments in PR Diff view forever

fields.description:
We would like the capability to restrict pull requests from being merged if the source branch does not have successful builds. However, we would like the ability to select which branches this restriction would apply to. 

The reason behind this is that in our case builds do not happen for our feature branches only our long running branches.
fields.summary: Require pull request successful build count for specific branches
